commentBody:
To My Favorite NYT Columnist

DÃ≤o eight lines of verse
EÃ≤ven the purse
BÃ≤etween Deb and I?
AÃ≤m I a fool to try?
MÃ≤an, it‚Äôs clearly not a fair trade,
LÃ≤ines of ragged doggerel,
EÃ≤ven if lovingly made,
NÃ≤o recompense for all she gave.

Deb, you are a light in this world, which I know will continue to shine. May your next chapter bring plenty of joy!  And, please, come back to visit (if not for us, then for the emus, who are reportedly inconsolable).

A new personal best!

I‚Äôll go to bed now with a happy glow, and be sure not to come back for the comments about this puzzle belonged on Tuesday.

Such a good puzzle!
Such great cluing, such great fill.

What a lovely puzzle from Hemant Mehta! I breezed through it in 11:07, just 1:05 shy of my Friday personal best. Came here to gloat, and to see whether ILLINOISE and NEPOBABIES were debuts. (I'm still not sure!) ü§™
I never heard of a yard of ale, Larry Nolan, or Illinoise, so that corner was a bit difficult.  Otherwise it was a bit light for a Friday.

This was a really fun Friday.  It required a bit of thought, but wasn‚Äôt stressful. Both clues and answers had a light quality.  The longish entries like LOOMEDLARGE and INADEEPHOLE just seemed to jump off the page.  A Seuss reference is always welcome, and I was happy to see a reference to ILLINOISE, which highlights the quirky music of Sufjan Stevens.  

I wonder how many NEPOBABIES come from BLENDEDFAMILIES.

Serendipitously, I got INSPO only because I learned it on Jeopardy just a few hours earlier.
Yard Ale? Don‚Äôt get it.
I thoroughly enjoyed this solve! was on its wavelength from the start and was able to just woosh in those long answers. Great puzzle!

These two answers in exact opposite corners were also responses on today‚Äôs episode of Jeopardy.

What are EDGAR and INSPO?
Nice chewy puzzle with some excellent, novel, clueing.  Among the best Friday puzzles in the past year.

I had a wonderful half hour with this pretty puzzle.

There was just one fun answer after another:  STUBBED TOES, BLENDED FAMILIES, SWAG BAG.

I thought FACETS for [Planes on a diamond] was a beautiful double misdirection--it had me thinking so hard about baseball diamonds I forgot about real diamonds, which, diabolically, was right.

Let's see if I can lure Andrzej back in....

Everyone, and I mean every one, has to appreciate the great pun in ILLINOISE, which I haven't seen but am sure is another in the line of wonderful musicals, where everyday conversations break into wondrous lines of song.  Who wouldn't like that?

I mean, it would take someone wholly without a soul to not appreciate that terrific pun and to give a tip about a new musical.

So I am going to regretfully and judiciously complain about this puzzle. And I want to be clear I am not throwing shade on this constructor, because this was a fabulous grid with many fresh interesting entries. But I really feel he was let down by the editors.
I was only a minute off my personal best here, despite a few interesting initial wrong entries‚Äîhome DECOR for one which is pretty close to DEPOT; EGG which could be an opportunity‚Äîand ADE which is certainly sold in a yard. And that‚Äôs also despite not knowing most of the proper nouns.
      So what‚Äôs the problem? So many interesting entries clued in absolutely the most straightforward, uninteresting way. And I have no idea if these are the editors‚Äô  or the constructor‚Äôs clues. This is not about me being on the same wavelength as the constructor, there is no other wavelength. CAT IN THE HAT‚Äîis there anyone who has read or seen this that won‚Äôt remember Thing One and Thing Two? Was there no other interesting bit of trivia or misdirection? Results of some remarriages‚Äî BLENDED FAMILIES‚Äîa marquee entry clued in the most straightforward way possible. FREESOLOED‚Äîclimbed without ropes. NEPOBABIES. DROPSDEAD. WAGEGAPS. I could go on. It spoils the few really clever clues (and there were some‚ÄîBASSDRUM, OPERAGOER.) Excoriate me if you wish but it really disappoints me to get so little satisfaction out of such otherwise glittering fill.
Maybe your experience was different, feel free to disagree.
Enjoyable to complete before bedtime. Thanks.

I felt some redirection was in order, that said started with the gimmes and it all worked out from there. 

I think this one had more terms that I could see my own generational and life experiences come through.  That is rare for a Friday for me. 

That said, woebegone those who complain ‚Äòbout a breezy Friday, for the Saturday Storm doth approach.
Why is "swim with the fishes?" clued with a question mark? That's literally what you're doing. If the fill was "GETTINGYOURBODYTHROWNINTHEOCEANBYTHEMOB" you'd use a question mark

Deb,

You helped me hang in there when I started solving in 2020. Your columns were funny and encouraging and I looked forward to them each week. Thank you!

All the best to you in your next adventures!

I‚Äôm here to crab about a musical entry before @Andrzej does. 

Nah, I‚Äôm not (though I admit that with ILLIN_ISE in place, I still wondered for a beat. ‚ÄúILLIN‚Äô what?‚Äù I wavered. ‚ÄúWISE? RISE? Could it be‚Ä¶ OISE? Are we rap-swearing at the French again? I‚Äôm‚Ä¶ in?‚Äù)

Actually, quick Friday that it was and long sleep-free night that it is, I took the time to read up a bit on ELSA Schiaparelli, whose crosswordese name I‚Äôd filled in easily as always but about whom I knew nothing. Did you know that, per Wikipedia, her ‚Äúdivided skirt‚Äîa forerunner of shorts‚Äîshocked the tennis world when worn by Lili de Alvarez at Wimbledon in 1931?‚Äù Or that she pioneered the wrap dress? Or the bra insert in our swimsuits? Her to-me-inexplicable fascination with Dali notwithstanding, she was‚Äî argh, it‚Äôs hard to come up with apt adjectives when sleep has eluded you for 7-plus hours. I do gently suggest you read up on your own. It‚Äôs a 15 minutes well spent. 

A good Friday to all.
Liked it.

The hotel at the weavers' convention had a loom with a view.

(They were weft to their own devices.)

Can this be a trend?  Finishing the puzzle with no look-ups?  Nah.  There were enough crosses to lead me through it, and ultimately it was the cleverness of the clues that resulted in some STUBBEDTOES ( I loved TOCK), and FREESOLO would be a lovely way to live if I didn't have the IDEALMATE. 

Amazing that the weekend is upon us and ball dop only a dozen days away.  The year is slipping through my fingers and I didn't really have time to live it.

Good cheer, my friends, and may the forth be with you.
Does the EPA still have geologists and biologists?

Just wanted to say how much I enjoyed this particular puzzle. I noticed a lot of new entries and I thought it was very clever. About 15 seconds over my average time and this one was a real pleasure to solve. Thank you.
Thank you for such a wonderful puzzle! I'm a big fan of wordplay over obscure knowlege, and was able to finish this Friday quickly (but not too quickly). More of this, please!

I ended up having to look for help for the top left corner, but im still new to solving friday/saturday puzzles without auto check! proud I got 90% of it on my own.

I love puzzles like this. Minimal weird dated trivia, minimal "crosswardese", the clever long pun answers are crossed by clues that can be deduced logically and with wit. a perfect puzzle!!

Too busy to puzzle last night, so before I did this one, I Q‚Äôd up yesterday‚Äôs. What a fun little appetizer that was! Then for the main course, I got to feast on this meaty gem. Delicious. And for dessert: not one, but TWO columns from Deb! Talk about a Gold Star meal.

And now, I need a nap. My compliments to the chefs.

As I mentioned to @SP earlier, this went by pretty quickly. I breezed through the majority of the grid, with my only hang up in the NW corner. I had Rav before REB which made it extra challenging until I let go of that answer. I still finished almost 10 minutes faster than my average and only a couple minutes off my PB. But the fill was just so good. Nice long answers and so many debuts. I watched FREE SOLO with a class of high school students in 2018 (Film as Literature) when I was teaching in Wisconsin. What a fascinating documentary. I agree with Hemant, if you haven‚Äôt seen it, you should! 
Thank you for the breezy jaunt, Hemant!!

Decades ago I subscribed to the International Herald Tribune and tried my hand at the crossword on long flights. I kept going with the international edition of the NYT until they spinelessly cancelled Chapate and editorial cartoons. I also cancelled them then. But I‚Äôve stuck with the puzzle. 

The best day of puzzling was when some time ago @Deb thought something I‚Äôd written was witty. 

I doubt I‚Äôll have another highlight like that. 

Thank you Deb for your kindness and guidance

We have been mailing cookies this week to friends and relatives using Priority Mail. Their slogan is, ‚ÄúIf it fits, it ships.‚Äù  I‚Äôll borrow that slogan for my solve. It was a delightful puzzle and, unusually, I can‚Äôt recall putting a wrong foot forward while solving. It all fit. 

Favorite entry was BLENDED FAMILIES. Mine was, ultimately ending up with six boys. For those birth order dinosaurs out there, I was Mom and Dad‚Äôs fourth child, Dad‚Äôs third child, Mom‚Äôs second child and their first child. Even today, when I‚Äôm asked my place on the roster, well, I do run on. 

And speaking of family‚Ä¶ Our recently formed multigenerational family, including my wife of fifty five years, our youngest son, his new bride and our two grandsons wish you all the happiest of holiday seasons. It‚Äôs our second holiday go around and it‚Äôs so nice to have children in the house again.

ELSA because I've seen that answer only five billion times, zero hope otherwise. 

Tough but I got lucky with these references, they clicked quickly... Except for ASTI. Gotta look that one up.

All the best Deb! I always enjoyed your commentary, insights, and enthusiasm. Like today, your excitement over debut entries got me excited about that as well! If the NYT Puzzle Team had jerseys like a sports team, you'd have earned your retired jersey number.

Hi Deb and everyone. 

For clue 30D - "Pitch catcher" - besides a business pitch, the EAR is the discerner of musical pitch.
FREE SOLO is certainly one of the best documentaries ever made. Even knowing ahead of time the climber lived while climbing El Capitan without ropes, it was nerve-wracking to watch.

Completed the left half (divided diagonally) in no time at all but at least most of the cluing was good if not challenging. 

@Deb, for EAR, I was thinking of a musical pitch, but your interpretation works too!

Excellent Friday puzzle, Hemant. I tried my hardest to shoehorn XTENDEDFAMILIES in. ;-)

Bon chance, Deb.

Sorry, but if it was up to me, no one would be allowed to free solo in Yosemite. I don't even have to watch the film to tell you that. 

I watched another film about a woman--I forget her name--who attempted to climb El Capitan and--oh, well, you don't want to know.

Why are people allowed to risk their lives this way???

Anyway, fun puzzle, lots of long nice answers.

Nice enough puzzle, but the clues seemed more like dictionary definitions than the misdirects I look forward to.  Those nice long debut entries, as well as most of the others, were just crying out for a little obfuscation.

Themeless Wednesday, anyone?
Today's puzzle actually took me about a minute less to finish compared to Wednesday's. 
I will miss you Deb, but I'm sure you'll DOOK in whatever comes next. Enjoy.

Saw Illinoise in Chicago before it moved on, and loved the album years before that.  REALLY good music, highly recommend.  

Best to Deb!

Possibly because I expected this to be more difficult, it took me a  bit to find my toehold (INERT/INFER) but it was a fairly easy climb from there.  The L in ALE/ILLINOISE the last to fall - yes, I thought of AdE too.  

I'll echo other comments, excellent grid but the clues could have been turned up a notch.  But still a fun one.  Thanks.

Oh, what a fun Friday puzzle! Just worked and worked and changed answers and fiddle and finally got it. DECOR instead of DEPOT had me stuck for a while. Just enjoyed this immensely. Thank you, Hemant! Y‚Äôall have a fantastic Friday!

I'd understand 3Down if it were "jamb".

What am I missing?

OOH, how I loved this puzz‚Ä¶

NE was the only sticky wicket,
not knowing DOLAN, 
and plopping in mgm for [Grande opening?]
realizing the e on the end made that a no-go,
and hastily plopping in ari instead, 
then thinking..gee..?

So many Grandes! 

So many grand clues 
and long entries so fresh 
they nearly deserved a slap!

Fantabulous Friday.
Nay, 
Fri-yay.
Fresh and fast

It's a shame that [Old money, for short?] wasn't PENNY.





Et tu, emu.

I did an inner backflip when I saw Hemant‚Äôs name atop the grid, as he‚Äôs one of my ‚Äúcan‚Äôt miss‚Äù constructors after just nine puzzles in the Times.  

His puzzles pulse with interest.  He averages close to nine NYT debut answers per puzzle, which makes his puzzles anything but same-old-same-old.  Today ten include the lovely FREE SOLOED, BLENDED FAMILIES, SWAG BAG, and can you believe CAT IN THE HAT has never appeared before?

Embiggening (Hi, @Deb!) the interest are the longs ‚Äì a soaring 15 answers of eight letters or more, including nine of the ten debuts.  Wow!

I also love the flowy grid design, never seen before in the Times.  I especially love that rectangular-ish white island in the middle formed by black squares. Look at how its four entrances connect it to the entire grid.  Mwah!

Coincidence: EDGAR and INSPO were answers just on Jeopardy.
Sweet serendipity: Two rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilaps ‚Äì TESSA and SPEED.

Once again, just a heap of loveliness, Hemant.  Thank you for this gem!
One more misdirect I had briefly‚Äîanyone else put ARI before RIO Grande? Guess I‚Äôve been watching too much Wicked.

I enjoyed all the long answers, with the assist of eleven 'easy mode' clues.  Thanks again to Christina Iverson!

Have a good weekend, everyone!

(And, yes, I also had 'Ari' before I put 'RIO'.  I love Wicked!)

Typical tough Friday for me, with a lot of things that weren't going to come to me just from the clues. But... a lot of working the crosses and things gradually fell together. Ended up being an enjoyable workout. Puzzle find today was inspired (in a roundabout way) by SWAGBAG. Anyway - a Thursday from March 18, 1999 by Rand H. Burns. Some answers in that one: SWAGMAN JUMBUCK TUCKERBAG BILLABONG and... WALTZINGMATILDA Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/18/1999&g=17&d=A ...

Read "Boomer playing in a band" and instantly entered BASSDRUM. Most of my solve went like that, so this one seemed very easy to me. Finished in 15 minutes, which is quite fast for me on a Friday. Had ZING rather than TANG briefly, until I saw FACET. Probably the most thinking I did for this one.

The fill here is outstanding. Curious what others thought of the challenge this puzzle offered.

Two nights without Andrejz? What's going on?

Deb,  please say this isn't your last column??

Had ideal date instead of ideal mate for the longest time. I know nothing about MERC so that got me. Lots of names today too which will never be my favorite. Otherwise, some great cluing! Happy Friday!
Now I can't get Tom Petty's Free Fallin' outta my head.

You know how sometimes nothing clicks and the puzzle is still half full of blanks after an hour? Well hallelujah, this didn't happen to me today! I don't know what came over me but I just sailed through this one. Its going to be a fine day.

Good puzzle today, on the easy side for a Friday.

I got hung up at the end cause I had IDEAL DATE instead of IDEAL MATE and had no idea about the "Planes of a Diamond" clue.
As a long-time reader of the Friendly Atheist blog I'm always happy to see Hemant's puzzle's come up (also they're always a fun solve!)

1D Annual Mystery Award
EDGAR

was also a clue on Jeopardy--(last night, I think). I'm not sure but I believe it was Final Jeopardy. I learned it was named for Edgar Allen Poe, (of course).

I was surprised to see that, when I finished, my time was around 30% under my average, mostly because I spent so much time laboring over the SE. On a personal note, I have never thought of a PEEP as a ‚Äútreat,‚Äù as 28D suggests, but I enjoyed the reminder of my late aunt Jeanette who loved them and always forgot I didn‚Äôt.

30D. When I envision a [Pitch catcher?], I imagine someone squatting over home base holding a catcher‚Äôs mitt. This is a business pitch, however, and the catcher would be another person‚Äôs EAR.

I simply thought pitch was a reference to sound and thus the ‚Äúear‚Äù is what is used to hear an unmodified voice warbling off-key.

One of those that seemed impossible at first, like for sure I was going to have to look something up, but I kept plugging away and ended up solving it without any help from google. Pretty proud of myself.

OOH.  I will try to get back here and read the Comments at some point, and I'm eager to see how many suckers cleverly entered BLUEBERRIES at 2D.  I certainly did.  Yessiree...hook, line, and sinker.  
And TICK before TOCK.
I held off at 42A, betting that many would enter FROG.  However, we high-schoolers started with a (huge) WORM, and next came a starfish and a fish before the frog, who was, alas, a female and chock full o' eggs!  Had to wait until college for the fetal pig.

I had MLS before MGS; in fact, my pill dosages are in MCGS.  (No caps.)

DHubby believes I am the last living person in the USofA who IRONs.  I am sure this is a gigantic misstatement, as every quilter has at least one IRON in frequent use.  I used to iron our napkins, but now I just fold them fresh from the dryer and put an "antique" iron (a "sad iron") on the stack; voila! Perfectly pressed overnight.
A nice change that the Grande Opening was not Ari  üôÇ
Are we just skipping over the fact that Illinoise won the Tony at the 2024 awards, not the 2023?
Deb, thank you so much for all that you do. Reading your column and comments has brought me great joy.

Not any problem, but xenon isn‚Äôt INERT.   The story of noble gases is wonderful science ‚Ä¶ overlooked at first by Mendeleev, eventually placed in the periodic table.  Helium observed first, but on the Sun, and then in a volcano.

Now dark matter, we think that is pretty inert.  If the space between us and the main stars in the constellation Orion was filled with solid lead metal, that dark matter would sail through.  Hope we figure that stuff out someday.  It is most of the stuff in the universe.
In many ways, this felt like an old puzzle with new clues aside from Illinoise and Nepo babies

When I posted earlier today, I was going to include a link to a song inspired by 38 A [Suddenly kicks the bucket], but I ran out of time searching for the version I wanted. I got in my car and the 3rd song in (WUMB at 5:56) was that song. I couldn't find a live version and most others were behind a paywall, but here's Paul Rishell and Annie Raines with Old Man Mose: https://youtu.be/DDAkD7BzwyE?si=Dckr-0hb6_Tvzyzj
Tripped up on idealdate vs. idealmate. Windy City exchange is new to me. Stuck until I got 33/34 figure out, but I got it.
Congrats on the debut! Extremely enjoyable! Loved the NE and SW stacks ‚Äì the cluing ‚Äì overall one of the best of late. More!
Nice puzzle-was worried when I saw Hemant's byline thinking it might be a stumper!

Thank you, Deb.  Your columns gave me the courage to move through the week and try the harder puzzles at the end of the week.  I will miss you and hope to see you commenting in this thread.  Best wishes for your future plans.

i keep seeing references to easy mode.
but i cant find it.
can someone splain me?
I don‚Äôt thing the constructor knows what a slow clap is!

Really enjoyed this Friday puzzle -- thank you, Hemant! Like others, I confess to going dark on "Swim with fishes?" I somehow wanted to squish in DAVYJONESLOCKERED or CEMENTSHOED, but, alas, the space and tense did not allow for me to go all Godfathery (new word not yet surfaced on Jeopardy).

Deb, as others have shared more eloquently, thank you for your kindness, wit and wisdom that has guided us through our Fridays and Saturdays (and a few other weekdays as occasional treats). Your humor and humility have provided me with greater end-of-week crossword courage and to no longer endure a hives outbreak when I see the word REBUS. My best to you for a well-earned, happy and healthy retirement. ü´∂üèº
Perhaps a little easier than I personally like for a Friday but still fun. Flew through it and finished about :20 away from a personal best
For 38A, I had "UP AND DIES" which caused a bit of a jam there until I figured out the proper colloquialism. I think I was being too Midwestern.

It's raining and super-windy here in New London CT, where submarine lingo is in our blood. We've had a few power blinks already. 
And now, puzzles are done, and I've no excuse but to get in the car and brave going to the office. Yes - just any minute I'll be standing up...I swear! 
Have a great day.
I enjoyed breezing  through this puzzle: 11 seconds over this week's Tuesday solve, 66% of my Friday average. Thanks for a fun solve.

Cheers to the English Comp nun who patiently explained the difference between "infer" and "imply!"
üíÉüèª
Missed it today but it was fair.  5 streaked last week and 4 streaked this week so still a best two week performance
One of my favs in a very long time. Sometimes I never get on the creator‚Äôs wavelength. Took a few stabs then, Zing oh I mean TANG.
Really enjoyed this one. Was totally vibing with Hemant. Looking forward to his next puzzle.
Didn't know MERC, so it took me a long time to change idealdate TO IDEALMATE
Really enjoyed that!  Just right for a Friday.  Little initial panic but then it all came together piece by piece.  Very satisfying - thanks!
Is anyone else having problems with the IPad app?   Mine asks me to update the program, but there is no update available.

Speaking of accelerando-ing, I've never had an experience like today's. I had not a single confident answer after my first pass through the across clues, and not even a guess in the top half except for NAN. It wasn't until going through the downs that I had my first sighs of relief, because they confirmed some of my guesses. I felt as though I had finally grabbed my rope and could clip in. Whew!

After my third pass or so, things started accelerating--and then I finished well below my current usual Friday times. I feel as though I just won a 20 yard dash. It was very quick, but oh so satisfying.

And now I can help my sister peel away all the coverings from her brand new floors and other surfaces before relatives start showing up later today. This was not a voluntary home makeover, but the end of a several-years enforced saga due to structural issues and we can all help her celebrate.

What a delightful puzzle! Fresh clues, fresh fill, and it must have been on my wavelength because all of my guesses turned out to be correct (with the exception of ARI before RIO), probably the first time this week that's happened. I didn't know most of the proper nouns, which kept things interesting. 
Thank you, Mr. Mehta, and thank you Deb for your constant wit and joy. You will be missed!

Wow! is this really Friday? Got a lot of the little bits and pieces and then the long ones stared to come tohether and i raced through this puzzle with glee.  Tasty stuff and lots of new ones (for me at least) 

Three Cheers
Nice Wednesday puzzle.  Needs more bite for a Friday.

30:36, 23:51 faster than my Friday average. Slow start but sped up midway.

The He or Xe misdirect was my favorite.

As a fellow Illinois native, I really enjoyed this fast Friday (especially after what was a tough Thursday for me). 

I have not seen the musical, but I highly recommend the album Illinoise. You don't have to be from there to like the music, but if you are, it's fun to note all of the niche references. I remembered when Pulaski Day was a school holiday. Other references include the Superman statue in Metropolis, the Lincoln-Douglas debates, the Columbian Exposition, and Little Egypt. 

I went on a memorable field trip to the MERC for high school Econ class, so that was a gimme. On another field trip to the Shedd Aquarium, we pulled a Bueller and spent the day roaming the city, getting back just in time to catch the bus back to the burbs. Good times.

This took me quite a while to finish ‚Äî the left 2/3 went very fast with LOOMED LARGE, NEPO BABIES, OPERAGOERS, BLENDED FAMILIES entered very soon. The right 1/3 was entirely another story! But I love a chewy Friday puzzle and this was no exception.
I have come to expect Hemant's puzzles to be lively and interesting and fun to do (also challenging)! Enjoyed this one a lot. NEPOBABIES for the win!

Late Friday afternoon and racing the sun, so tonight's candle has to go up a bit earlier and can't just piggyback on a 'real' post.

Have a lovely weekend.

Six nights and counting!

I did not like this puzzle for too much use of obscure clues. Especially the NE corner. I know Fridays are always more difficult and I completed without lookup and in my normal time but just felt the puzzle was boring and used obsolete terms‚Ä¶ But that is just me, others may have thought it was too easy. üòÇ

I liked this one. 

Am I getting better/smarter or are the puzzles getting easier? Asking for a friend‚Ä¶.

Well, I saw several ‚Äútoo easy‚Äù complaints, but for me this terrific puzzle was both challenging and fun and I want to thank the constructor for bringing it to us. NEPO BABIES was new to me and that was the last corner I conquered. Sports teams‚Äîalso terms‚Äîare always tough too, and I got my husband‚Äôs help with those. My very favorite entry was CAT IN THE HAT, because once when I was teaching at an elementary school, another teacher and I dressed as Thing One and Thing Two for the Halloween parade with all the students and staff. We were a hit!üòÑ

I'm fairly certain the pitch that the EAR is catching is, in fact, the pitch of a sound.

Unrelated: I had SeverED TOES for 3D for a while. I have no idea how that came to my mind.
Enjoyed this Friday, nice surprise for me !

I think these are easy if you know the trivia.
Otherwise...
Cool to see Justin Peck‚Äôs ILLINOISE in a puzzle. Hooray for choreographers‚ù£Ô∏è

I must have been on the same wavelength as the constructor! I have never finished a Friday so fast (especially with no lookups). 13:50, ten minutes faster than my average Friday. It helped that I managed to think of BLENDEDFAMILIES and NEPOBABIES with only one or two crossings, and THECATINTHEHAT was a gimme. Fun puzzle with lots of good words!

Mostly fun puzzle with some delightful fill, but MERC/EDIE is a vicious natick for those of us from abroad, especially when 33a could easily have been IDEAL DATE. Possibly I'm just too young to be anything other than icked out by calling a partner a "mate."

More amusingly, got completely tripped up by pattern recognition, fully expecting "Grande opening?" to be the ever-present ARI. Pleasantly surprised to have been wrong!

TIP-IN, not TaP-IN ! ü§¶  I was thinking tap-in sounded viable, maybe for golf? Now I‚Äôm guessing maybe ‚Ä¶basketball? 

I was on-track for a better-than-average Friday time until I spent several minutes searching for the error in the filled grid.

One more late puzzle find, inspired by our constructor's name. A Wednesday from July 22, 1987 by James R. Burns. Four answers in that one: SEIJIOZAWA FRITZREINER GEORGESZELL ZUBINMEHTA Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=7/22/1987&g=57&d=A ....

I did not care for this puzzle. Too much Gen Z slang like "INSPO", "NEPO BABIES", "SWAG BAG".

I had never heard of many of the proper names before:
ELSA Schiaparelli,
ILLINOISE,
EDIE Windsor,
nor TESSA Hadley.

I was not on the same wavelength as today's constructor. I felt like I was having an awkward cocktail party conversation with a person with whom I shared nothing in common.

Still surprised at the suboptimal nature of NYT game software. If I solve on my phone and Mac alternately, even if I close the app, I sometimes return to find that the clock has been running the whole time. My solve times are absurdly long. I once took a week or two off and it was comical how long I was solving away. Come on NYT this isn't on me to fix.
This one gave me BRUISEDTOES which really screwed up my AMiITION.
KETO is specifically a low carb diet. Cluing it as high fat seems odd. Yeah, you are having the replace the calories from carbs with something, but typically more protein than fat.
Wow PB for a Friday! Finished on FACET (not CARET or any variation thereof)
disappointed that 10a. fire in one‚Äôs belly? wasn‚Äôt DIARRHEA
The clue for 3D should be "jamb" not "jam", no? Threw me a bit...

@Puzzlemucker Great to see a post from you! And in fine form for Deb‚Äôs farewell. When I started solving in 2020, Deb‚Äôs column drew me in, gave me encouragement, and helped me feel at home in this community. Your posts were a highlight of my formative years here, too. Many thanks and best wishes to you both!

@M. Biggen

While we're sharing our love of @Deb, I posted the following late last night, and to share it better, I'll reprise it here:


What I‚Äôm loving about the kind posts about @Deb today are that they are written with warm hearts.  Oh, Deb‚Äôs job has been to explain the theme and tricky clues, and she has done that skillfully.  That‚Äôs all she‚Äôs really had to do, but she‚Äôs gone ‚Äì day after day ‚Äì the extra mile.

You know you‚Äôre going to feel good reading Deb. She touches such a lovely place in the heart, makes it go ahhh and smile.  Part of it is how genuine she is ‚Äì she‚Äôs never trying to impress.  No, she‚Äôs wanting to help, wanting to share when a funny thought hits her.  Rooting for the new solvers while at the same time making observations that experienced solvers can relate to.

Lots of specifics for why Deb is special, but to me it‚Äôs mainly the je ne sais quoi, the magic. She has a talent for that, and I‚Äôm so grateful for it.  What a gift you‚Äôve been to the Times and to us all.  It‚Äôs been a great run.

@john ezra

Completely blown away!  The wonderful thing about poetic constrictions is what they can produce. I didn‚Äôt fully realize that until I started trying to make poems out of crossword words.  Every anagram you manage to use is a stunner, though BLED AMEN stands out to me because I doubt that phrase has ever been used before and yet it has such poetic resonance.  Just a gorgeous, brilliant, beautiful poem.  Wow!

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Your erudition knows no bounds!  My favorite poem as a teenager was Robert Herrick‚Äôs ‚ÄúUpon Julia‚Äôs Clothes,‚Äù perhaps because it was short enough to easily recite. I still love it and him and the Susan Cooper stanza is lovely.

@Puzzlemucker, thanks mate! I loved loved loved your acrostic -- we really are in her DEBt. 

Interesting that today's puzzle features the spanner BLENDED FAMILIES, which anagrams to...

Deb Amlen fidelis! (Basically what this thread's message is)

Deb Amlen is filed! (What we will say sadly when Deb posts her last column on Jan. 2)

...and beginnings of sentences you will never hear: "If Deb Amlen's idle..." (Since an idle Deb Amlen is unimaginable)

@Vaer

My favorite Wordplay debate.

While I'm enjoying the many tributes to Deb Amlen - my favorite Wordplay columnist  - my first reaction was a panicked "Wait, is this her last column? NO!"

So I checked, and happily the answer really IS "No"; we have two more weeks to savor her wit, warmth, enthusiasm, and encouragement.  Phew!

@Jonathan

It's not terribly uncommon to find ALE clued with a reference to a "yard" (which is a really tall pub glass).

Just two weeks ago on Wednesday, December 3, the clue for ALE was "Drink that may come in a yard".  Friday, June 13, 2023: "It might be sold by the yard".  Saturday, January 28, 2023: "Product that may be sold by the yard".  Sunday, November 7, 2022: "Something that may be sold by the yard". Saturday, November 6, 2021: "It's sold by the yard". The list goes on.

Today's twist on the familiar cluing, though relatively novel, is hardly unprecedented -- check 11D on Friday, April 24, 2009!

@Jonathan. The yard of ale has been around for the better part of four hundred years, being well attested in Britain in the seventeenth century. As the name suggests it is about a yard long mostly slender with a flared top and a bulb bottom. It holds somewhere around 3 US pints of beer. Currently it is mostly used for drinking games. 
I own a half-yard glass picked up in a brewery in the mid 70s.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

You aren't taking into account the blended families.  It's a logic puzzle: prior to their marriage to each other, Dad had two children and Mom had one child. So Kevin D was their first child *together*, Dad's third, Mom's second, and their fourth overall.

Speaking of mailing cookies, I mailed four each to my brother in San Francisco and my sister back in Buffalo. $16 Oy!

I made springerles, a traditional anise flavored German cookie.  I used to make these and others with my mother on wintry Buffalo days many years ago. There‚Äôs a special rolling pin used only for springerles that leaves a pressed design on each cookie. I inherited mom‚Äôs so it‚Äôs my job to make these each Christmas.

@Nancy J.I once knew a woman who did extreme sports and from what she described it was like a compulsion, and not in a good way.  Stemmed from stuff that happened in childhood, and seemed that there was no way for her to feel alive other than to be risking her life.

@lucky13
Why? Because, in most western thought, if it's your life you have the right to risk it. No permission needed. It is the same line of reasoning that supports MAID policies. 
Among counterarguments are the social costs of rescues, ongoing medical costs, and the morality of maintaining and promoting what the law calls 'attractive nuisances'.
There are other ways of thinking of our relations to our own bodies. They regard us as tenants rather than owners. Here the challenges to freedom and autonomy are the difficulties.
Our family proverb: There are no solutions but you do have your choice of problems.

@John
Within the past week NYT updated the Puzzles app and it now requires a more recent version of iOS which older iPhones and iPads cannot receive. MANY complaints about this in the NYT Puzzles reviews on the App Store. 

The main reason for this update: embedded advertising In the newer version of the app. (Websearch "interstitial advertising"). That's what NYT is loading into the Puzzles app. You get to pay to subscribe to an app that will be increasingly pushing ads at you between puzzles. Happy Holidays!

You can continue to use the old version of the app, for now, though for how much longer remains to be seen; at some point, I expect the app will not load.
